title: Old Man Hemlock's Humility
devotional:
Old Man Hemlock, as everyone called him, wasn't old in years, perhaps just past sixty, but he carried himself as if burdened by centuries. He shuffled, head down, avoiding eye contact, always mumbling apologies, even when no offense had been given. He volunteered to clean the church toilets every week, a task no one else wanted, and performed it with meticulous, almost obsessive care. No one ever saw him smile. 

One day, a new pastor, fresh out of seminary and full of youthful zeal, decided to 'fix' Old Man Hemlock. He pulled him aside after service. 'Brother Hemlock,' he began, his voice booming with well-intentioned encouragement, 'you are a child of God! You deserve to hold your head high! Stop apologizing! You need to embrace your worth!' He then proceeded to deliver a mini-sermon on self-esteem, complete with Bible verses about being 'fearfully and wonderfully made.'

Old Man Hemlock listened patiently, his head bowed even lower. When the pastor finished, he simply nodded and shuffled away. The next week, he cleaned the toilets as usual, but this time, the pastor made a point of observing. He watched as Hemlock scrubbed, his face etched with what the pastor interpreted as sorrow. Determined to break through, the pastor interrupted him. 'Brother Hemlock! I want you to stop that! You're worth more than scrubbing toilets! Let someone else do it!'

Hemlock stopped, straightened slowly, and looked the pastor directly in the eye for the first time. His gaze was surprisingly intense. 'Pastor,' he said softly, 'this isn't about worth. This is about service. This is about reminding myself that I am no better than anyone else, and probably worse. This is about keeping myself low, so God can lift me up. This is my humility.'

The pastor, taken aback, realized his well-meaning advice had completely missed the mark. He’d mistaken Hemlock's quiet demeanor for low self-esteem, when it was, in fact, profound humility, a deep understanding of his place before God.
image_description: A worn and well-used bar of soap sits on the edge of a porcelain sink, next to a scrub brush.
insights: Humility isn't about self-deprecation or a lack of confidence; it's about recognizing our dependence on God and valuing others above ourselves. Philippians 2:3-4 states, 'Do nothing out of selfish ambition or vain conceit. Rather, in humility value others above yourselves, not looking to your own interests but each of you to the interests of the others.' True humility leads to genuine service and a willingness to take on even the most undesirable tasks.
prayer: Lord, forgive me for the times I've equated humility with weakness. Help me to understand true humility as a posture of dependence on You and a genuine concern for others. Give me the grace to serve with a humble heart, not seeking recognition or praise, but simply reflecting Your love to those around me. Show me the areas in my life where pride has taken root, and help me to cultivate a spirit of humility in all that I do. In Jesus' name, Amen.
reflection: In what areas of your life do you struggle with pride? How can you practically demonstrate humility in your relationships and service to others? What tasks do you avoid because you feel they are 'beneath' you, and how can you reframe your perspective to see them as opportunities for humble service?
